content.title: The day New Brunswick switched to driving on the right - CBC News
content.desc: Traffic anarchy. Head-on collisions. Confused horses. No one knew what to expect on Dec. 1, 1922, when New Brunswick switched to the right-hand rule of the road at the stroke of midnight. For as long as anyone could remember, drivers in the province had obeyed the left-hand rule of the road — handed down from the province's colonial past. Before 1922, New Brunswickers drove on the left side of the road. The old left-hand traffic pattern is clearly visible in this 1920 photo of a a funeral procession in Saint-Léonard taken from l'Hôtel Cyr. The change caused a sensation — inspiring advertis...
